message: Anyone was able to get real-time web apps running on mainstream browsers? Ruby, Python, .net, Java, Node, etc?

data.message: i used SignalR , and worked like a charm for me + works fine on Mobile Browsers too. i liked it because it takes care of fall back for me. and make your code a little bit high level of abstraction.
I don't get your question Tayseer, are you looking for a web app framework or looking for some person who managed to develop using such a thing?

Yes, we built an entire platform in erlang with bindings for ruby and php via rest apis and websockets on the client side that falls back to flash then comet.
Full support for IE8+, Firefox, Chrome, Safari and Opera. Why?

I'm learning about real-time web technologies in the past few days. I'm trying with pure Python & I was able to create some demos, but nothing works on IE8 yet (except Firebase). I wanted to see the experience of others as well
I used SignalR in .Net and Atomsphere in JAVA both work on main browsers and mobile chrome

Node is not a magic bullet :) its single threaded approach isn't novel either, non-blocking io and event loops models hit mainstream long ago. Node.js only made it accessible. You'll still need to implement a backend for the proper protocols/techniques (websockets, comet...etc) Or use a library, same applies for any other platform.

We packaged the product commercially Mohammad Tayseer but it's been defunct for almost a year now so we might open source it.
Try socket.io, it has many fallback backups. I use it with nodejs and tested it on firefox, chrome and an android app that I've built.
Tayseer: For IE8 you should fall back to long-polling. No new tricks would work
but it allows 1400-1800 concurrent connection. check this before you decide to use it. http://drewww.github.io/socket.io-benchmarking/

I think the best frameworks for this exist in .NET and Node. When it comes to old platforms compatibility you are already beyond simple solutions already most of the time, so, it helps to use a framework that covers the edges instead of rolling up something simple on your own.

If you are thinking on expansion to 1Million con current connection for example it will be depending on your infrastructure. I would think of making a central socket as a balancer that distribute the traffic to various servers.
